igcop 0.1.0.9000
  • Reference
  • Changelog

IG Copula Family Functions

ig.Rd

Functions related to the IG copula family, denoted by 'ig'.

pcondig21(v, u, cpar)

qcondig21(tau, u, cpar)

qcondig(tau, u, cpar)

pcondig(v, u, cpar)

qcondig12(tau, v, cpar, mxiter = 80, eps = 1e-12, bd = 5)

pcondig12(u, v, cpar)

dig(u, v, cpar)

logdig(u, v, cpar)

pig(u, v, cpar)

rig(n, cpar)

Arguments

u, v

Vectors of values between 0 and 1 representing values of the first and second copula variables.
cpar

Vector of length 2 corresponding to the copula parameters theta>0 and alpha>0, respectively.
tau

Vector of quantile levels between 0 and 1 to evaluate a quantile function at.
mxiter

Maximum number of iterations to run the Newton-Raphson algorithm when computing inverse. Positive integer, default 20.
eps

The Newton-Raphson algorithm for computing an inverse will stop if the step size is less than this small number.
bd

The largest acceptable step size in the Newton-Raphson algorithm. Step size is reduced if it reaches this large.
n

Positive integer. Number of observations to randomly draw.

Value

Numeric vector of length equal to the length of the input vector(s).

Note

Inputting two vectors greater than length 1 is allowed, if they're the same length. Also, qcondig21 and pcondig21 are the same as qcondig and pcondig -- they're the distributions of variable 2 given 1.

Examples

set.seed(1)
u <- runif(10)
v <- runif(10)
pig(u, v, cpar = c(5, 1))

#>  [1] 0.07998850 0.09248525 0.46307012 0.36915934 0.18767583 0.47424038
#>  [7] 0.69702131 0.66064796 0.29172181 0.05846469
dig(u, v, cpar = c(2, 2))

#>  [1] 1.0949890 1.0328600 1.0258831 0.8253385 0.9488539 0.8400993 0.9415070
#>  [8] 1.2682942 0.9214325 0.8553771
logdig(u, v, cpar = c(2, 2))

#>  [1]  0.09074430  0.03233167  0.02555377 -0.19196166 -0.05250043 -0.17423516
#>  [7] -0.06027354  0.23767289 -0.08182576 -0.15621280
pcondig21(v, u, cpar = c(3, 6))

#>  [1] 0.2059765 0.1765546 0.6794343 0.3837089 0.7863289 0.4960070 0.7068927
#>  [8] 0.9873761 0.3796761 0.8153175
qcondig21(v, u, cpar = c(3, 6))

#>  [1] 0.2059726 0.1765589 0.6949935 0.3845008 0.7546750 0.4994238 0.7291069
#>  [8] 0.9947989 0.3803962 0.7442596
pcondig12(u, v, cpar = c(3, 6))

#>  [1] 0.26568654 0.37220495 0.59720796 0.90874810 0.22671056 0.90028096
#>  [7] 0.94829038 0.44152809 0.63118042 0.07042358
qcondig12(u, v, cpar = c(3, 6))

#>  [1] 0.26533079 0.37204284 0.54733005 0.90766428 0.17877750 0.89646254
#>  [7] 0.94080742 0.79626601 0.62703647 0.05417459
rig(10, cpar = c(3, 3))

#> # A tibble: 10 x 2
#>         u     v
#>     <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 0.935  0.537
#>  2 0.212  0.547
#>  3 0.652  0.531
#>  4 0.126  0.179
#>  5 0.267  0.768
#>  6 0.386  0.652
#>  7 0.0134 0.669
#>  8 0.382  0.108
#>  9 0.870  0.809
#> 10 0.340  0.402
